Text: China's annual CO2e production-based emissions in 1994 totaled 4208.3Mt CO2eq. This represents 11% of total global GHG emissions and makes China is the 2nd contributor of GHG emissions. The average person in China emits 3.5t CO2e, making it the 112nd per capita GHG emitter in 1994. The AFOLU sector makes up 16% of the global GHG emissions, with enteric fermentation and agricultural soils representing respectively 37 and 32 of the 688Mt CO2e. These quantities have been computed using the AR4 global warming potential 100-year time horizon relative to CO2.

China's annual CO2e production-based emissions in 2005 totaled 8062.8Mt CO2eq. This represents 17% of total global GHG emissions and makes China is the 1st contributor of GHG emissions. The average person in China emits 6.2t CO2e, making it the 84th per capita GHG emitter in 2005. The AFOLU sector makes up 11% of the global GHG emissions, with agriculture and land-use change and forestry representing respectively 100 and 0 of the 856Mt CO2e. These quantities have been computed using the AR4 global warming potential 100-year time horizon relative to CO2.

China's annual CO2e production-based emissions in 2010 totaled 10574.1Mt CO2eq. This represents 22% of total global GHG emissions and makes China is the 1st contributor of GHG emissions. The average person in China emits 7.9t CO2e, making it the 54th per capita GHG emitter in 2010. The AFOLU sector makes up 9% of the global GHG emissions, with agricultural soils and enteric fermentation representing respectively 30 and 29 of the 904Mt CO2e. These quantities have been computed using the AR4 global warming potential 100-year time horizon relative to CO2.

China's annual CO2e production-based emissions in 2012 totaled 11926.8Mt CO2eq. This represents 23% of total global GHG emissions and makes China is the 1st contributor of GHG emissions. The average person in China emits 8.8t CO2e, making it the 50th per capita GHG emitter in 2012. The AFOLU sector makes up 9% of the global GHG emissions, with agricultural soils and enteric fermentation representing respectively 35 and 26 of the 1034Mt CO2e. These quantities have been computed using the AR4 global warming potential 100-year time horizon relative to CO2.

China's annual CO2e production-based emissions in 2014 totaled 12200.3Mt CO2eq. This represents 24% of total global GHG emissions and makes China is the 1st contributor of GHG emissions.
